headline: The Red Cross
title: The Red Cross
creator: Thomas, Esther E.
description: After the outbreak of World War I and subsequently the Spanish Influenza the American Red Cross mobilized thousands of individuals. In Moscow, to combat the war the Red Cross did everything they could from knitting socks to preparing bandages to be sent to soldiers. When the Spanish Influenza came to the area they served as nurses, made flu masks and prepared meals for patients. Esther Thomas was a member of the American Red Cross beginning in 1917 by 1918 she served as a nurse at the university for patients of the influenza.
subject: Red Cross; nurses; World War I; spanish influenza
source: MG 170, Esther E. Thomas. Scrapbook, 1915-1919, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives
rights: Material has passed into Public Domain based on date of creation. Digital reproduction permissions assigned by University of Idaho Library. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

title: Inland Hospital Postcard
creator: Ott, Clifford M.
description: Postcard depicting Dr. Carither's Inland Hospital, Moscow, Idaho. In 1918, while Dr. Carither's was serving the nation, he allowed Inland Hospital to be used for Spanish Influenza patients from the university's Student Army Training Corps.
subject: hospitals; moscow; buildings; spanish influenza
source: PG 90, Clifford M. Ott Collection, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives
rights: Material has passed into Public Domain based on date of creation. Digital reproduction permissions assigned by University of Idaho Library. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

title: President Ernest H. Lindley
description: Lindley served as President of the University of Idaho from 1917 to 1920. Beginning his presidency the same year the United States entered World War I, Lindley dealt with a loss of male students to the military, the establishment of the Student Army Training Corps on campus, and the outbreak of the Spanish Influenza.
subject: University of Idaho; administration; portraits; photograph; university; presidents; spanish influenza; world war I
source: PG 3, University of Idaho Portrait Collection, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes. Digital reproduction permissions assigned by University of Idaho Library. title: U. Temporarily Closed Three Mild Cases of Flu - Page 1
creator: University Argonaut
description: The article indicates the the university took the precautionary measure to close the school temporarily in order to prevent the spread of the Spanish Flu when three members of the S.A.T.C.'s vocational corps were found to have mild cases.
subject: University of Idaho; closures; spanish influenza; disease; epidemic; pandemic; illness; preventative measures; S.A.T.C.; Student Army Training Corps; cases

title: Everybody Must Wear Flu Masks - Page 1
creator: University Argonaut
description: Subheaded 'Washington Orders Rush ocal Red Cross and Aides,' the article discusses the order from the government that all patients of the spanish influenza were required to wear face masks, and how the Red Cross and sorority members were making the masks for the patients.

title: Moscow People Care for the Sick - Page 3
creator: University Argonaut
description: Subheaded 'Victims of Influenza Are Being Cared for Better Here Than Elsewhere,' the article praises the work of the university and military administration, as well as the women in Moscow in their care for influenza patients.

title: Football Practice Is Postponed - Page 2
creator: University Argonaut
description: Subheaded 'Lieut. Meehan Looks Forward to Brilliant Seaseon for Teams,' the article discusses the postponement of football practice due to the influenza epidemic. The acting coach is waiting on word from Dr. Kotalik before practices may restart.

title: Student Petition

title: Telegram from Biwer Secy to President Lindley, October 20, 1918
creator: Secy, Biwer
description: Biwer Secy informs President Lindley that the State Board of Health has closed all public and private schools, and enacted a quarantine on on state institutions.

title: University Affiars Feel The Quarantine - Page 2
creator: University Argonaut
description: Subheaded 'Regulations of Health Board Affect Many Social Events,' the article indicates that though the UI campus has 'not yet' had cases of the Spanish Flu many student activities are banned by the State Board of Health.

title: Letter from Commissioner E.A. Bryan to President Lindley, November 2, 1918
creator: Bryan, E.A.
description: Commissioner Bryan responds to letter from President Lindley on the status of the influenza. He celebrates that the state has had only slight losses to the influenza.
